channel.title: Silwood Computer Skillz Workshop
channel.description: Every two weeks on Thursday in the Boardroom from 17:00 (Bring your own booze!)

item.title: R notebooks
item.description:
On the 1st of June session, Natalie showed how to use R markdown to use R studio like a pro!

This was a nice follow up to last session on Markdown. In fact, Natalie showed us how to use markdown in R studio in order to write a complete notebook using R notebooks. You can see her cool entire module written all in markdown as a book (with chapters and everything). For more details, have a look at her repository that has all the nuts and bolts (don’t hesitate to clone/modify!).

item.title: Markdown
item.description:
On the 18th of May session, I (Thomas) showed how markdown is the answer to everything if you want to write down things.

Markdown is a really easy to use language. You can find details on it’s syntax on over here: Daring Fireball Dingus.

One of the major advantage though is that you can use it as a portable writing format and convert it into any kind of language using pandoc. Check out this PeerJ paper for more details.

Finally you can also use Markdown for your normal coding via knitr in R or Rstudio…

item.title: GIS pipelines
item.description:
On the 20th of April session, Jack showed us how how to create easy analysis pipelines for both ArcGIS and GIS in R.

ModelBuilder in ArcGIS is an efficient way to queue processes as well as iterating over objects and files. Models can be saved in a toolbox and used again later or applied to new data. They can also be converted into ArcPy scripts.

QGIS has graphical modeller which is extremely similar.

GIS processes can also be carried out in R. See this script for an example.

item.title: Open Tree of Life
item.description:
On the 30th of March, Dimitris showed us how to use the Open Tree of Life in a R pipeline. Great stuff for phylo analysis (especially for getting backbones or constraints)!

Check the Open Tree of Life project here and check Dimitris’ example here (running smoothly on GitHub!).

item.title: Jupyter
item.description:
On the 16th of March session, Samraat made a nice and easy demo of how to use Jupyter and integrate it into collaborative workflows.

Check Jupyter here and check Samraat’s example here (running smoothly on GitHub!).
